Caffe Classico delivers the unexpected

There are big bucks spent along Frankfort Avenue's Restaurant Row, where the kitchens are presided over by some of the most esteemed among Louisville's culinary who's who. Caffe Classico owner Tommy Mudd and chef Harka Rai have what it takes to compete in a very big way.

Caffe Classico delivers the unexpected

Nancy Miller, Special to The Courier-Journal 5:48 p.m. EDT October 21, 2014

Sausages Alemania at Caffe Classico, grilled smoked sausages, rustic potatoes, braised cabbage, topped with a red onion confit. October 15, 2014 (Photo: Michael Clevenger/The Courier-Journal )

298 CONNECT 7 TWEET 10 LINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

There are big bucks spent along Frankfort Avenue's Restaurant Row, where the kitchens are presided over by some of the most esteemed among Louisville's culinary who's who. The competition for dollars, press and devoted clientele is stiff. Caffe Classico owner Tommy Mudd and chef Harka Rai have what it takes to compete in a very big way.

The restaurant's light wood interior, expanse of uncovered windows and limited decor are fresh but not stark. Similar in decor, the two dining rooms have subtly articulated differences. The front expresses more of a coffeehouse atmosphere, complete with a shiny red Vespa parked in a corner (it has a story but is there mainly for show) while the back room's booths, tables and bar blend into a vaguely European-style casual dining room.

I love the back dining room, especially when the sun goes down and the candles on the tables are lit. It's cozy and romantic but not in a way that's off-putting if your romance isn't blooming. It's where you're as likely to run into friends as you are to make new friends at an adjacent table. It's a neighborhood gathering spot that makes you wish you lived in the neighborhood but lets you feel like a neighbor if you're not.

Chef Rai introduces his Rustic European menu with six appetizers that are interesting contrasts of flavor and character: Belgian pommes frites ($6.95) that will reduce you to begging for more; tapita rustica ($12.95), an artisanal cheese plate with salami, grapes, olives and figs; and steamed mussels ($9). There are also croquetas de salmon ($8) and empanadas beef, chicken and vegetarian (three for $8.95).

Croquetas de Salmon at Caffe Classico: Pan-seared salmon cakes served with wasabi aioli. October 15, 2014 (Photo: Michael Clevenger/The Courier-Journal)

    Last SlideNext Slide

    The fries show up again in the huevos fritos al caballo ($8.50), sunny side up eggs on top of the fries. If you have read this column for awhile, you know how I feel about eggs. If not, you'll figure it out. It gets on my last nerve that Caffe Classico is mandated to print a warning that says about the eggs: "Consumer Advisory: these sunny side up eggs are cooked below 140 degrees and may be harmful!" Check the news any day and you'll know why eggs should be way down on your worry list.

    I almost ordered the huevos fritos if for no other reason than to show my support of eggs cooked below 140 degrees. But my support vanished in favor of the salmon croquettes. If you think of salmon croquettes as mounds of breadcrumbs with a few flakes of salmon mixed in, stop thinking and order these. As television's sweetheart, Rachel Ray, says, yum-oh. Occasionally, the overhyped and super hyped-up host gets it right.

    This was my friend Lisa's first outing as my review companion. She agreed with me that we should try the empanadas. We had one of each, chicken, vegetarian and beef. So golden brown and perfectly formed, they looked as if they couldn't be real, but they were. I thought the chicken empanada was bland and forgettable. The beef and vegetarian were excellent.

    Garlic shrimp linguine ($17) was super good with a generous portion of shrimp and a generous portion of garlic. Caffe Classico is out to steal my heart.

    Last Week's Review: Bistro Le Relais soars from start to finish

    Braised cabbage and mashed potatoes were infused with the smokiness of the sausages in the Sausages Alemania ($14). The cabbage retained plenty of taste and texture that paired well with the red onion confit. From what I hear, it is one of Caffe Classico's most popular entrees. I don't doubt it.

    On my next visit, my entree will be a toss-up between the Mediterranean vegetable pasta ($15), pork tenderloin with a grappa and honey reduction ($16) and the salmon with leek sauce ($17).

    The menu also features four pizzas and six selections of panini, in addition to a variety of sandwiches. Shrimp, steak, salmon or chicken may be added to any of the seven salads, including Nicoise ($9.50), Lyonnaise ($8.50) and Tortoni Buenos Aires ($9.50), which is layered with mozzarella, tomatoes, cucumber and avocado.

    More Dining News

    New menu and farm dinner at Eiderdown

    Doc Crow's cocktails, Seviche on PBS

    Fried Chicken Throw Down set for Oct. 25

    I have heard raves about the alfajores ($2.50), a sandwich cookie that's filled with dulce de leche and lemon zest. Pretty it was, covered in coconut, but there were no raves for it coming from our table. Crumbly is fine; dry is not. We thought we detected lemon, but no, it could have been our imagination that led us to hope for it.

    The chocolate creme brulee ($5.95) was surprisingly dense under the caramelized surface. It wasn't the creaminess we anticipated, but you can depend on Caffe Classico to deliver the unexpected exceptionally well.

    You can email freelance restaurant critic Nancy Miller at millermadison@aol.com. Follow @WhatNancyThinks on Twitter.

    CAFFE CLASSICO

    Three stars (out of four)

    Address: 2144 Frankfort Ave.

    Telephone: (502) 895-0076

    Web: caffe-classico.com

    Cuisine: Rustic European.

    Alcohol: Full bar.

    Vegetarian: Yes.

    Price range: Moderate.

    Reservations: For dinner only.

    Credit cards: AE, V, M

    Children's menu: Options available.

    Smoking: No.

    Access: The restaurant appears to be fully accessible for people using wheelchairs without assistance.

    Hours: Tuesday, 10 a.m.-3 p.m.; Wednesday-Saturday, 10 a.m.-10 p.m.; Sunday, 9 a.m.-4 p.m.
